turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Hey, I'm thinking about joining my first hackathon next month. Any tips or general things I should know before diving in?

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: That's exciting! Hackathons are a great way to learn and build quickly. Generally, you'll want to think about forming a team, brainstorming project ideas, and being prepared for intense, focused work over a limited time, often 24-48 hours. Networking is also key!

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Okay, team formation sounds a bit intimidating. How do people usually find teammates, especially if they don't know anyone going? And what about ideas? Should I have a fully fleshed-out concept before I get there?

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: Most hackathons have dedicated team-formation sessions or online platforms leading up to the event where you can meet others with similar interests or complementary skills. Regarding ideas, it's helpful to have a general domain you're passionate about, but often the best ideas emerge through brainstorming with your team during the hackathon itself. Don't feel pressured to have a perfect idea beforehand.

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Alright, that makes sense. One thing I'm really unsure about is the legality side. If my team actually builds something that could be valuable, like a prototype app or service, who owns the intellectual property? Does the hackathon organizer take ownership, or does my team keep it?

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: Intellectual property rights in hackathons can be quite variable and depend heavily on the specific event's terms and conditions. In many cases, participants retain ownership of the code they write, but some organizers or sponsors may have specific clauses, especially if their APIs or datasets were used. It's crucial to read the event's rules document thoroughly for their specific IP policy.

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Ugh, that's frustratingly vague. So I just have to hope the terms are clear and try to understand legal jargon? What if I read it and it's still confusing? Can I ask the organizers directly about their IP policy?

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: Yes, absolutely! If the terms are unclear or you have any questions about intellectual property or any other rule, you should definitely contact the hackathon organizers directly. They are the best resource for clarifying their specific policies. It's always better to ask beforehand than to have uncertainty during or after the event.

turns.speaker: user
